context: 2.2.4 Sequential dosing isotherm method Isotherms were obtained for uncoated and coated materials using an automated sequential dosing method. Equilibrium sorption isotherms for LHA were collected in an associated study (Bell and LeBoeuf, in press). In order to evaluate equilibrium behavior of TCE onto these model soils, a sequential dosing method with the Micromeretics ASAP 2010 was used. The ASAP 2010 is equipped with a hydrocarbon manifold so liquids that possess a vapor pressure of at least 1mm Hg at room temperature and <10μm Hg at liquid nitrogen temperature could be used as sorbates in obtaining equilibrium isotherms (TCE meets this requirement). Vapor phase equilibrium isotherms were collected at experimental temperatures of 15°C, 25°C, 35°C, 75°C, 95°C, and 115°C corresponding to three temperatures above and three temperatures below the glass transition temperature of LHA (Tg =74±3°C (DeLapp et al., 2004)). Samples were degassed on one of two degas ports. Degas temperatures were 105°C for all samples with the exception of the highest temperature isotherms at 115°C in which case the degas temperature was 115°C.
